AND SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW.

PRINCE ALBERT, N. W. T., WEDNESDAY, JULY 11, 1883.

$2.50 A YEAR.

AUCTION SALE
OF VALUABLE PROPERTY.
CANADA.
NORTH WEST TERRITORIES.

In the Saskatchewan District Court, Sunday, July 26th.

In the matter of LYDIA VERONICA MCKENZIE, WILLIAM SAMUEL MCKENZIE, JOSEPH TAYLOR MCKENZIE, JOHN PATRICK MCKENZIE, AGNES GEORGIA MCKENZIE, GEORGE SIMON MCKENZIE, SAMUEL LAURENCE CLARK, BENJAMIN COLIN CLARK, JOHN THOMAS MCKENZIE, WILLIAM ROSS indoors under the age of twenty-one years, by GEORGE THOMAS MCKENZIE, their next friend.

All persons who may be interested in the property will have an opportunity to examine the same, and bids will be received at the Office of the Auctioneer, Prince Albert, N.W.T.

PRINCE ALBERT, N. W. T.

BOOTS AND SHOES.

Shannon & McLeod,
Boot and Shoemakers.
Have opened offices in Macarthur & Knowles' old bank building, where we will pleasure to serve the public of Prince Albert. Our remaining display cases by strict attention to business, hope to merit a share of their patronage.

We expect our stock of Ready Made Boots and Shoes to arrive in about two weeks.

SHANNON & McLEOD,
First door east of Campbell's Block.

CHURCH MATTERS.

The following items were received by the Rev. Canon MacKay:

Dear Canon MacKay,

We, the undersigned members of the congregation of St. Mary's Church, have applied to His Lordship, the Bishop of the Diocese of Saskatchewan, to have the Rev. Canon MacKay appointed to the parish of St. Mary's, and guarantee him a salary of $1,000 per annum for three years.

We trust that you will be able to see our wishes realized in this matter.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

To the Hon. Lawrence Clarke, Capt. H. S. Moore, and others.

Gentlemen,

I have received your communique of June 13th, and most sincerely thank you for your kind expressions of sympathy to me and your desire, backed by a most generous personal guarantee, that I should become permanently your parish priest.

Well, my dear friends, I have had little cause from time to time during long absences from home, both in my ministerial and social life, and it gives me great pleasure to say that I have never experienced any lack of kindness.

In conclusion, may God bless you all and send you many happy returns of the year.

Yours sincerely,

J. A. MacKay.

COMMUNICATION

QUEEN'S BIRTHDAY SPEECH
To the Effect of The Times.

Sir,—I understand that the Queen's Birthday Speech will be delivered at the close of Her Majesty's Speech to the Canadian Parliament this morning. I am sure that the Speech will contain many pleasant surprises for her subjects.

With best wishes,

[Signature]

ASH & ROBBINS,
Patton & Brody, Brooklyn.

CARROT RIVER.

From an occasional correspondent.

A Methodist minister is reported to have visited Carrot River this week.

Subscriptions for the school house are being circulated.

There is a large amount of breaking up going on at this place.

A trip is being made up Dominion Bay to Water Hole Lake. A most enjoyable time was spent.

In conclusion, I have to express my regret that I could not attend the celebration last Saturday evening. All the land that was surveyed last year has been taken up.

Mr. J. B. Riley, late of Prince Albert, is now in residence at Carrot River, in the opinion that Kinistino has a great future before it, as it is backed by first rate lands.

Building operations are keen, twenty new buildings have been erected since this spring. There is a general air of prosperity throughout the town.

SASKATCHEWAN.

An extensive "ungraded water" is situated on the north side of Beaver River, about nine miles from the present telegraph crossing.

This land is in the property of the Temperance Colonization Company, who have given 300 lots free, on condition that they are occupied by settlers.

The town was landed lately by the directors of the Company.

Mr. Lown and Mr. Lown, Colonization Managers, will settle here for some months to look after the interests of the settlers.

Church at Kinistino is in good order, but needs to be beautified or partly finished.

There is a general air of prosperity throughout the town.

Spring fairly families have arrived here.

The first birth in the town occurred a couple of weeks ago.

It is expected that there will be a large influx of settlers before many weeks are over.

The following will be the other settlements planned to make rapid progress, as it has this spring, and will prove liberating, as many who have been living in tents, etc., will be comfortable in their own homes.

Hargreaves being built at Medicine Hat for supplies down to the main camp.

The Canadian Government will open a post office at Victoria, B.C., in a few days.

The Dominion government will open a post office at Medicine Hat for supplies down to the main camp.

The Canadian government will open a post office at Victoria, B.C., in a few days.

Hargreaves being built at Medicine Hat for supplies down to the main camp.

The Canadian Government will open a post office at Victoria, B.C., in a few days.

A CLEAR CASE

Anchors have been found in the river.

ITEMS OF INTEREST.

The Military College at Kingston has closed.

A cyclone at Chili has been visited by an earthquake.

The Dominion police force are now equipped with rifles.

Secretly a man has been drowned in the flooded streets.

Gen. Sir William Knollys, retired, is dead. He was born in 1767.

A conciliation commission has been made to settle the纠纷.

Fifty cases of death from yellow fever occurred at Havana last week.

Mr. Tirard, French minister of finance, has been called to life again.

At St. Louis the river is still rising but more slowly than heretofore.

Her Majesty's condition continues to give the physicians great anxiety.

The festival of the Assumption was celebrated by a procession at Quebec.

Mexican troops have made heavy repulsions upon invading forces at Chihuahua.

A large majority from Germany is reported among the whites at Vera Cruz.

Dr. Lushier, the noted national liberal leader of Germany, has arrived at New York.

Tony Jones, a negro, was hanged at Toronto, for the murder of a fellow workman.

The Marquis of Toscana asserts that Cossacks will not relinquish their sovereignty of Austria.

Pongol, Louise Michel's confidant, received a sentence of eight years imprisonment.

Three hundred and fifty dollars have been collected at Montreal for the Farrell testimonial fund.

Mr. Hoad, United States Minister at St. Petersburg, is about to leave that city on business.

Lord Ripon will be made Duke on his return, in recognition of his great services in India.

A report is current at Shanghai that the French and their Annamite allies have landed in Japan.

Immense damage has been done to crops and property by floods in southern and southwestern Nebraska.

Hon. Mr. Macdonald received a visit from the Liberal of St. Hyacinthe, who tendered him a banquet.

Another party of minor orphan children from France have arrived at the Marquette home, Belleville.

The Ottawa and Gatineau Valley and Ottawa Colonization railways have been sold to an American company.

Official returns give Quebec four thousand four hundred schools and two hundred and thirty-six thousand pupils.

The bill to incorporate the Great Western Ship Canal Company has passed the Massachusetts Legislature.

A hospital has been established at Danville in connection with the outbreak of a deadly type of cholera.

Receiving against the Jews was resumed at St. Paul, where the predominant diagnosis dispensed the mob.

The North German Oracle says His master is recovering from a violent cold which has retarded his progress.

The Canadian Mutual Telegraph Company has now passed into the control of the Great North Western Telegraph Company.

Frank Thacker, aged four, at Cambridge, N. Y., had his eyes poked out and his nose and head horribly cut by a gun shot.

HUDSON'S BAY CO.'Y.

FARMING LANDS!

FOR SALE IN

Manitoba & North-west

The Hudson's Bay Company own 5,000,000 acres in the Great Belt Belt, and new offer for sale of 500,000 acres already surveyed by the Government of Canada.

ALSO

TOWN LOTS

FOR SALE

In Winnipeg, West Lynn, Rat Portage, Portage la Prairie and Goucheen, N.W.T.

This offer will be disposed of at reasonable prices and on easy terms of payment.

Full information in regard to these lands will be given at the offices of the Company in Winnipeg and Montreal.

C. J. BRAYTON, Land Commissioner.
